title: Trump Got Dow 36,000 Author to Forecast the Coronavirus. It Didn’t Go Well.
description: Why did Trump keep citing impossibly low death totals? Kevin Hassett, who is neither a public-health expert nor a good economist, made a model.
author: Jonathan Chait
content: President Trumps habit of promising unrealistically low casualty counts is one of the more inexplicable unforced errors in the administrations handling of the coronavirus pandemic. One is too many, he said on April 20, but were going toward 50 or 60,000 peopl… [+4008 chars]

title: Dow futures fall nearly 300 points Sunday evening as U.S. states attempt coronavirus reopenings
description:
U.S. stock-index futures fell sharply in thin trading Sunday evening as investors contended with state reopenings, with cooped-up citizens eager to to gather as spring has brought warmer weather conditions. Futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average were off 288 points, or 1.2%, at 23,331, those for the S&P 500 index declined 31.45 points, or 1%, at 2,790.25, while Nasdaq-100 futures retreated 88.25 points, or 1%, at 8,629.75. More than two dozen U.S. have begun to allow select businesses to open or announce plans to do in May, but local and federal officials are also facing climbing cases of novel cases of coronavirus, albeit, at a slower pace. The COVID-19 pandemic has killed nearly 250,000 people world-wide and infected 3.5 million, with 1.154 million in the U.S. alone, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University. Meanwhile, investors may pay close attention to the airline industry after Warren Buffett, during an annual shareholder meeting on Saturday, said that his Berkshire Hathaway had sold all of its stake in major airlines, Delta Air Lines Inc. , Southwest Airlines , United Airlines-parent United Airlines Holdings Inc. and American Airlines . On Friday, the Dow fell 622.03 points, or 2.6%, to end at 23,723.69, while the S&P 500 gave up 81.72 points, or 2.8%, to settle at 2,830.71. The Nasdaq Composite Index retreated 284.60 points, or 3.2%, closing at 8,604.95.

title: Dow falls 622 points and stock market wipes out weekly gains to start May amid worries about China, Amazon and Apple
description:
U.S. stocks started the first trading day in May on a downbeat note after notching the best April for the benchmarks in years. The day's losses wiped out weekly gains and were mostly reflective of the magnitude of the surge in the prior month and concerns about the earnings prospects for the likes of Amazon.com Inc. and Apple Inc. , dominant technology-related firms that have been at the vanguard of a recovery for the market from a coronavirus-induced selloff that hit a low in late March. On Friday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down more than 622 points, or 2.6%, at 23,724, marking its worst day since April 21, while the S&P 500 index ended down 2.8% at around 2,831 and the Nasdaq Composite Index closed down 3.2% at about 8,604. For the week, the Dow ended off 0.2%, the S&P 500 booked a 0.2% weekly decline and the Nasdaq looked a 5-session loss of 0.3%. Shares of Amazon ended the session down by more than 7% after the company said that it would use its profits to spend on protecting its workers during the COVID-19 pandemic, raising the question about costs for companies during the public health crisis. Separately, shares of electric-vehicle maker Tesla Inc. finished the session off by more than 10% after its CEO Elon Musk tweeted that the share price of the company had gotten too high. Shares of Apple finished down 1.6% after the company declined to provide guidance for its coming quarter. Investors also were watching developments between the U.S. and China amid threats of tariff retaliation against the world's second-largest economy for its handling of the novel strain of coronavirus, which was first identified in Wuhan in December.

title: Dow falls more than 600 points Friday afternoon amid signs of China-U.S. tension and hazy outlooks from Amazon and Apple
description:
U.S. stock benchmarks on Friday were trading sharply lower to start the first day of trading in May as uncertainty from the outlooks from Amazon.com Inc. and Apple Inc. eroded some of the optimism that helped the Dow and S&P ring up their best April gains in 82 years. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was off 630 points, or 2.6%, at 23,720; the S&P 500 index fell 89 points, or 3%, at 2,824, while the technology-laden Nasdaq Composite Index declined 3.5% at 8,577. Late Thursday, Amazon said coronavirus-related costs such as employee testing and higher wages added to expenses and would likely in the future. Meanwhile, Apple declined to provide guidance for the current quarter. Adding to the bearish tone, President Trump indicated he may consider imposing tariffs on China, for their role in handling the novel coronavirus outbreak, which was first identified in Wuhan, China. Separately, shares of Tesla were under pressure after the CEO of the electric-vehicle maker, Elon Musk, tweeted that the company's share price was too high.

title: Dow erases hard-fought weekly gains with 630-point slide Friday afternoon
description:
U.S. stock benchmarks on Friday wiped out their gains for the week as a decline for the equity gauges accelerated near midday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 644 points, or 2.6%, at 23,702, with a weekly decline of less than 0.3%, the S&P 500 index was sinking 3.1%, headed for a weekly drop of 0.5%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index was down 3.6% on the session, and on pace for a weekly slide of 0.7%. All three had started the session looking at positive gains for the week, after April proved one of the best advances for stocks in years, as investors attempt to adopt a more bullish tone in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic. Worries about the outlook for corporate earnings in the face of the epidemic and signs rising tensions between the U.S. and China centered on the handling of the infectious disease, which was first identified in Wuhan, China, all helped to sour the market mood.

title: Dow tumbles more than 250 points at open as investors face earnings deluge
description:
U.S. stocks fell at the opening bell on Thursday as investors sifted through a stream of earnings reports from blue-chip companies, looking to understand how executives dealt with the upheaval resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic. The S&P 500 was down 0.7% to 2,918. The Dow Jones Industrial Average tumbled 263 points, or 1.1%, to 24,371. The Nasdaq Composite was down 0.1% to 8,905. Economic data underlined the disruption to the once-robust labor market, with initial U.S. jobless claims surging by another 3.8 million last week. Economists estimate the unemployment rate is now above 15%, since the coronavirus outbreak forced businesses to shutter and workers to stay home in mid-March. In company news, shares of Facebook Inc. rose 5.7% despite earnings falling short of Wall Street estimates.

title: Dow's profit falls in line with expectations, sales beat
description:
Shares of Dow Inc. slipped 0.2% in premarket trading Thursday, after the materials science company matched profit expectations but topped sales forecasts, and said it was taking further measures to strengthen its financial position amid the COVID-19 pandemic. Net income rose to $258 million, or 32 cents a share, from $208 million, or 24 cents a share, in the year-ago period. Excluding special items, adjusted EPS fell to 59 cents from 98 cents but matched the FactSet consensus. Sales fell 11.3% to $9.77 billion, amid lower local prices due to a decline in energy prices, but topped expectations of $9.71 billion. Volume fell 2%, as growth in demand for food, health and hygiene packaging; surfactants and solvents for cleaning; and coatings was more than offset by declines in polyurethanes and silicones. Dow said it was beginning to see indications of recovery from COVID-19 in China. The company is further reducing its capital expenditure target to $1.25 billion, below the 2019 target of $2.0 billion, and trimming operating expenses by $350 million. The company is idling some manufacturing units. The stock has dropped 22.7% over the past three months through Wednesday, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average has declined 14.6%.

title: Dow falls 340 points as total jobless claims hit 30 million, likely bringing unemployment to Great Depression levels
description:
U.S. stock-index benchmarks on Thursday fell at the open after a report on those seeking unemployment benefits showed another big increase, as expected. Initial jobless claims rose 3.839 million in the week running from April 19 to April 25, with experts expecting 3.5 million, according to economists polled by MarketWatch. The unprecedented surge in layoffs has likely pushed the unemployment rate above 15% to the highest levels since the Great Depression, economists estimate. Total claims are around 30 million in the latest week. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 344 points, or 1.4%, at 24,300, those for the S&P 500 index slipped 1.1% at 2,906, while the Nasdaq Composite Index traded off 0.6% at 8,864.

title: Dow books nearly 300 point loss, as stocks hold onto double-digit gains in April
description:
U.S. stocks fell modestly on Thursday, but left their double-digit percentage gains for this month intact, after a round of mixed corporate earnings and a report that the federal government was considering retaliating against China for its handling of the coronavirus. The S&P 500 fell 0.9% to 2,912. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 288 points, or 1.2%, to 24,346, based on preliminary numbers. The Nasdaq Composite was down 0.3% to 8,890. For the month, the S&P was up 10.9%, the Dow rose 11.1%, and the Nasdaq gained 15.5%. Economic data pointed to the pain felt by households. Nearly 3.8 million people filed for unemployment benefits for the first time in the most recent week, the Labor Department said. Adding to the bearish market sentiment, the Washington Post later reported that the Trump administration was considering retaliatory actions against the Chinese government for its lack of transparency about the seriousness of the outbreak.

title: Dow ends lower as Washington Post reports U.S. 'crafting' retaliation against China for coronavirus handling
description:
U.S. stocks midday Thursday took a firm leg down midday but finished off the worst levels of the session after the Washington Post reported that U.S. officials were "crafting retaliatory actions against China' as the Trump administration criticizes the world's second-largest economy for its handling of the COVID-19 pandemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 288 points, or 1.2%, at 24,346, the S&P 500 index ended off 0.9% and the Nasdaq Composite Index dropped 0.3%, with all the benchmarks closing well off their worst levels of the day. The coronavirus was first identified in Wuhan, China in December and Trump has recently railed against what he has described as the country's lack of transparency around the severity of the outbreak. Meanwhile, the New York Times reported the Trump officials have "pushed American spy agencies to hunt for evidence to support" an unsubstantiated theory that the novel strain of coronavirus was derived from a laboratory in Wuhan. The pandemic has infected more than 3 million people world-wide and claimed more than 230,000 lives, according to data compiled by Johns Hopkins University.

title: Dow futures shoot up 200 points as U.S. crude rallies
description:
U.S. stock index futures shot higher Tuesday night as U.S. crude prices rallied. Dow Jones Industrial Average futures were last up 200 points, or 0.8%, while S&P 500 futures and Nasdaq-100 futures each gained more than 1%. Meanwhile, June West Texas Intermediate crude , which closed 3% lower Tuesday, jumped around 15% in electronic trading Tuesday night, to just above $14 a barrel. U.S. stocks closed lower Tuesday, squandering early gains, as tech stocks took a hit ahead of earnings reports. Wednesday is one of the busiest days of earnings seasons, with Facebook, Tesla and Boeing, among others, reporting. Investors are also looking forward to comments Wednesday by Fed Chairman Jerome Powell, who is scheduled to speak as the Fed wraps up two days of meetings. While no major moves by the Fed are expected, Powell is expected to give a message that the central bank has the current crisis under control.

title: Dow holds strong gain after Fed vows to use full range of tools to help prevent prolonged damage from coronavirus
description:
U.S. stock markets rose Wednesday afternoon after the Federal Reserve kept rates unchanged, as expected, but vowed to do whatever it takes to help the economy bounce back from the public-health crisis created by COVID-19 pandemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 522 points, or 2.2%, at 24,620, the S&P 500 index rose 2.6% at 2,937, while the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 3.4% at 8,895. In a statement following its two-day meeting of the policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee, the central bank said: "The ongoing public health crisis will weigh heavily on economic activity, employment and inflation in the near term, and poses considerable risks to the economic outlook over the medium term." The Fed kept its benchmark rate close to a range of 0% and 0.25% and repeated it would hold policy steady until the economy has weathered recent events and "is on track" to achieve full employment and price stability. That is unchanged from the March forward guidance. The Fed has already reduced a key interest rate to near zero and increased its balance sheet to $6.6 trillion, adding $2.2 trillion over the course of the past few weeks, as it doled out funds to help prop up the U.S. economy during the coronavirus pandemic. A news conference hosted by Fed Chairman Jerome Powell will be held at 2:30 p.m. Eastern Time.

title: Dow ends at highest level in 7 weeks as Gilead's coronavius treatment and Fed's pledges help to bolster stocks
description:
U.S. stocks finished at their highest level in weeks on Wednesday as investors assessed progress on treatment for the novel strain of coronavirus and the Federal Reserve pledged to use its policy tools to help limit the economic damage from business shutdowns intended to slow down the spread of the contagion. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose around 530 points, or 2.2%, at around 24,633, marking its highest level since March 10, the S&P 500 index advanced 2.7%, at about 2,940, representing its highest close since March 6, while the Nasdaq Composite Index closed up 3.6% at 8,915. All levels are on a preliminary basis. A benchmark of small-capitalization stocks, the Russell 2000 index surged more than 5%, highlighting an area of the market that has made a powerful surge higher after being badly left behind during the coronavirus-induced rout in March, which hurt small businesses the most. Helping set the stage for gains on the day was a host of data from Gilead Sciences , which showed that its anti-malarial drug remdesivir was successful in treating certain patients with COVID-19. Meanwhile, the New York Times on Wednesday reported that the Food and Drug Administration is preparing to grant an emergency-use authorization as early as Wednesday. That news came after a series of data points from clinical trials were shared publicly, including promising results of a Gilead-sponsored trial, a positive preliminary data analysis from a National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases study, and data from a Chinese clinical trial published in The Lancet. Meanwhile, the Fed kept interest rates at a range of 0% and 0.25% but said that it intends on doing whatever is necessary to help support an economy and market beleaguered by the viral outbreak.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.

title: Dow surges more than 400 points at Wednesday's open amid upbeat report on Gilead's experimental coronavirus treatment
description:
U.S. stocks surged higher Wednesday morning, supported partly by upbeat data on a trial of experimental treatment from Gilead for the novel strain of coronavirus. Gilead Sciences Inc. announced data from two clinical trials testing its experimental drug remdesivir in severely ill COVID-19 patient. Market participants have been eager for an effective treatment for the deadly pathogen that has killed more than 212,000 people and infected more than 3 million world-wide since emerging in Wuhan, China in December. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 426 points, or 1.8%, at 24,531, the S&P 500 index gained 2% at 2,918, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 2.1% at 8,787. Meanwhile, the Federal Reserve will conclude its two-day meeting with a statement, due at 2 p.m. Eastern, followed a half-hour later by Chairman Jerome Powell's virtual news conference.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.

title: Dow books 530-point gain as stock-market advance intensifies after Fauci says Gilead coronavirus trial drug is 'quite good news'
description:
U.S. stock benchmarks added to strong gains Wednesday afternoon to finish sharply higher after Dr. Anthony Fauci described data from a drug trial of Gilead Sciences' remdesivir showed "quite good news," in treating certain patients stricken with the illness from the novel strain of coronavirus. Comments from the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Disease, at a news conference at the White House come after Gilead's remdesivir met the main goal in a closely watched government-funded clinical trial treating hospitalized COVID-19 patients but another study, also disclosed on Wednesday, found that the therapy did not lead to clinical improvement in patients in China. Remdesivir is widely considered to be a front-runner among the investigational therapies being tested as treatments for infections caused by the novel coronavirus. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 532 points, or 2.2%, at 24,633, the S&P 500 index rose nearly 2.7% at 2,940, while the Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 3.6% at 8,915. Of a possible vaccine, Fauci said: "We're going to have a lot of shots on goal when it comes to vaccines."

title: Financial stocks rally, give near 60-point boost to the Dow's price
description:
Financial stocks were enjoying a broad rally Tuesday, as the easing of coronavirus-related lockdowns in some states helped provided a boost to the sector and the broader stock market. The SPDR Financial Select Sector ETF rallied 2.4% in premarket trading, with only 2 of its 66 components trading lower. At the same time, the futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average surged 383 points, or 1.6%, with 28 of 30 components gaining ground. Among the Dow's financial components, shares of J.P. Morgan Chase & Co. rose 3.0%, Goldman Sachs Group Inc. advanced 2.2% and American Express Co. climbed 1.8%. The implied price gains of the Dow's financial components would add about a combined 57 points to the Dow's price.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
title_cleaned: FINANCIAL RALLY GIVE 60POINT BOOST DOW PRICE

title: Dow's earnings reporters add nearly a net 50 points to the Dow's price, led by 3M's stock rally
description:
The four components of the Dow Jones Industrial Average that reported first-quarter earnings Tuesday are providing a net boost of about 47 points to the Dow's price, with 3M Co.'s stock adding the most and Merck & Co. Inc.'s stock the only one acting as a drag. Shares of 3M rallied 4.7% to add about 49 points to the Dow, Pfizer Inc. rose 2.43% to add about 6 points and Caterpillar Inc. gained 0.7% to add about 5 points, while Merck fell 2.4% to shave about 13 points off the Dow to reverse earlier premarket gains. Meanwhile, Dow futures surged 422 points, or 1.8%, ahead of the open.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.

title: Dow jumps more than 300 points at Tuesday's open, nears best level since early March as lockdown easing fuels bulls
description:
U.S. stock benchmarks opened higher Tuesday morning, with analysts citing progress toward easing coronavirus lockdowns as investors weighed earnings from blue-chip companies, including Merck and 3M Co. , Caterpillar and Pfizer . The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 361 points, or 1.5%, at 24,505, the S&P 500 index advanced 1.4% at 2,818, and the Nasdaq Composite Index climbed 0.9% at 8,807. The gains for the S&P 500 and the Dow put them at around their highest levels since early March. In corporate news, shares of 3M Co. were up ahead of the opening ball after it announced earnings and sales that beat expectations, while withdrawing its outlook for the full year. Shares of PepsiCo Inc. rose after the beverage giant topped Wall Street expectations for sales but missed on earnings, while withdrawing its financial guidance for the rest of the year due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Dow erases 380-point gain Tuesday morning as tech-related and health-care shares drag stock market lower
description:
The U.S. stock market lost ground Tuesday morning, turning negative as the benchmarks were weighed by declines in shares of health-care names and those linked to information technology. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was off up 73 points, or 0.4%, at 24,045, but had been at an intraday high at 24,512, while the S&P 500 index was down 0.5% at 2,865 after hitting an intrasession peak at 2,921. The technology-laden Nasdaq Composite Index was down 1.2% at 8,624, but had been up 8,830 earlier in the short session. Investors' enthusiasm had been bolstered by hope of staggered reopening plans in U.S. states after the country has been shutdown to help stem the outbreak of COVID-19. Shares of health-care companies Johnson & Johnson , UnitedHealth Group Inc. and Merck & Co. were the biggest drags on the broader market and the Dow.

title: Dow ends 350 points higher as coronavirus lockdowns begin to ease
description:
Stocks rose Monday, kicking the week off on a positive note, as several European countries, and some U.S. states, began or outlined plans to begin lifting lockdowns put in place to contain the COVID-19 pandemic. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose around 354 points, or 1.5%, to end near 24,129, according to preliminary figures, while the S&P 500 advanced around 41 points, or 1.4%, to close near 2,878. The Nasdaq Composite jumped 96 points, or 1.1%, to finish near 8,730.

title: Dow gains early Monday to kick off busiest week of earnings season, rising as oil futures get punched in the mouth
description:
U.S. stock indexes on Monday rose, with equity markets apparently buoyed by hope, as lockdowns procedures are eased in parts of the country and other parts of the world. Sentiment around reopenings appeared to overshadow renewed devastation in U.S. crude-oil markets . Meanwhile, investors braced for a deluge of first-quarter earnings reports. There are 149 S&P 500 companies and 12 components of the Dow scheduled to deliver results this week, including those from the likes of Apple Inc. and Microsoft Inc. . Early Friday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average was up 131 point, or 0.5%, at 23,902, the S&P 500 index advanced 22 points, or 0.8%, at 2,858, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 77 points, or 0.9%, at 8,711. In other corporate news, General Motors said it would suspend its dividend and stock repurchases to preserve cash. Meanwhile, U.S. oil prices for June delivery were down nearly 30% on Monday, with the contract below $13 a barrel and flirting with its lowest level since 1999.

title: Dow set to rise to within range of 50-day moving average, S&P 500 set to get back above it
description:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average is about 455 points away (1.9%) from its widely followed 50-day moving average, which it has closed below since the COVID-19-related selloff took shape in late February. Many chart watchers use the 50-day moving average (DMA) to gauge the short-term trend. The Dow has remained in range of the 50-DMA since April 17, the Dow closed at 24,242.49 versus and the 50-DMA came in at 24,558.42. The 50-DMA extends to about 23,970 on Friday, according to FactSet. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 is even closer to its 50-DMA, as it extends to about 2,807 on Friday, or 0.3% above Thursday's close. The S&P 500 had closed slightly above its 50-DMA on April 17, when it closed at 2,874.56 and the 50-DMA was at 2,863.09. Dow futures were up 184 points while S&P 500 futures were up 0.9%.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.

title: Dow's slight loss briefly deepens as JAMA Network report recommends against using chloroquine to treat COVID-19
description:
Jittery U.S. stocks on Friday midday briefly took a slight dip lower after a medical report indicated that the primary outcome for an anti-malaria drug being reviewed as a treatment for COVID-19, was death. The JAMA Network Open, in a peer-reviewed report, recommended that the use of chloroquine, touted by President Donald Trump, shouldn't be used for the treatment of severe COVID-19, based on preliminary findings. A study of the drug was cut short because the primary outcome of the treatment in higher doses was death, the JNO report showed. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was trading down 0.2% at 23,475, but had touched a low at 23,417, while the S&P 500 index was virtually unchanged at 2,799 and the Nasdaq Composite Index was holding on to a gain of 0.2%. The markets have been on edge this week as investors look for upbeat signs that the U.S. will be able to emerge from lockdowns and stay-at-home procedures but in place to limit the spread of the deadly contagion. Earlier, the Food and Drug Administration also warned against using chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine outside a hospital or formal clinical trial setting.Corrections & Amplifications: An earlier version of this article misidentified the medical publication that authored the report on anti-malarial drugs. The report was from the JAMA Network Open, an open access medical journal published by the American Medical Association. The Journal of the American Medical Association, or JAMA, is a separate peer-reviewed medical journal. MarketWatch apologizes for the error.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
title_cleaned: DOW SLIGHT LOSS BRIEFLY DEEPENS JAMA NETWORK REPORT RECOMMENDS AGAINST USING CHLOROQUINE TREAT COVID19

title: Dow pares some gains after reports say Gilead's remdesivir shows disappointing results
description:
U.S. stock indexes Thursday afternoon lost some ground from intraday highs after a article on a closely followed therapeutic intended to help treat COVID-19 was reported to have shown disappointing results in a trial, according to an article by the Financial Times and Stat News. A clinical trial on the Gilead Sciences's drug remdesivir had been viewed by the World Health Organization and accidentally published, the FT reported. The FT said that researchers studied 237 patients, giving the drug to 158 and comparing their progress with the remaining 79. The story indicated that the drug showed significant side effects in some, with 18 patients taken off it. A WHO spokesperson told Stat that the manuscript is undergoing peer review and was published by accident. Earlier this month Chinese authorities had halted two trials for remdesivir, saying that there weren't enough patients to fully enroll the studies.The Dow Jones Industrial Average was bouncing around in afternoon action, well of its highs, and was trading up 123 points, or 0.5%, at 23,589, the S&P 500 index was up 0.5% at 2,812, while the Nasdaq Composite Index was up 0.6% at 8,551. Meanwhile, shares of Gilead were down nearly 4% Thursday. A report last week from Stat News indicated that remdesivir was seeing some success but the research linked to that report was not based on a clinical study. A Gilead spokesperson was quoted as saying in Stat that reports of the research "included inappropriate characterization of the study."

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
title_cleaned: DOW PARES GAINS REPORTS GILEAD REMDESIVIR SHOWS DISAPPOINTING RESULTS

title: Dow futures wobble after weekly jobless claims rise 4.4 million, signaling all the jobs created after the financial crisis are gone
description:
U.S. stock-index futures trade mixed Thursday morning, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq-100 headed slightly higher after the latest weekly report on those seeking unemployment benefits showed that 4.427 million people applied for unemployment benefits in the week ended April 18. That figure pushes total claims to more than 25 million. In the prior four weeks, new jobless claims soared by 5.25 million, 6.6 million, 6.9 million and 3.3 million respectively, using figures adjusted for seasonality. Futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 5 points, or less than 0.1%, at 23,366, and has been jumping in and out of positive territory. Those for the S&P 500 index climbed 0.3% at 2,795,75, while Nasdaq-100 futures picked up 0.3% at 8,659. For the week so far, the Dow is off 3.2%, the S&P 500 is down 2.6% and the Nasdaq Composite Index is down 1.8%, as of Wednesday's close. The employment figures have been slammed by shutdown procedures intended to mitigate the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
title_cleaned: DOW FUTURES WOBBLE WEEKLY JOBLESS CLAIMS RISE SIGNALING JOBS CREATED FINANCIAL CRISIS GONE

title: Dow futures pull back slightly Thursday evening as House passes bill to replenish coronavirus-aid package
description:
Dow futures retreated Thursday evening as the U.S. House of Representatives passed a much-awaited $484 billion coronavirus aid package that includes a second round of funding for small businesses under the Paycheck Protection Plan, or PPP. Futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average slipped 51 points, or 0.2%, at 23,285, those for the S&P 500 index were off 10.30 points, or 0.4%, at 2,779.50, while Nasdaq-100 futures retreated 51 points, or 0.6%, at 8,547.75. The measure, which comes after extensive negotiations between Democrats and Republicans, contains about $320 billion for a PPP meant to help small businesses. It also has about $75 billion for hospitals, $25 billion for coronavirus testing and $60 billion for the Small Business Administration's Economic Injury Disaster Loan program. The moves for stocks in thinly traded equity market futures in after-hours action Thursday come after stocks ended mixed in regular trade ended 4 p.m. Eastern Time. The Dow closed up more than 39 points, or 0.2$, at 23,515.26, the S&P 500 fell less than 0.1% to reach 2,844.90, while the Nasdaq Composite Index ended virtually unchanged at 8,494.75. Markets finished well off their highs of regular trade Thursday as a report throw cold water on hopes of a clear-cut treatment for COVID-19, after a report from the Financial Times suggested that trials of the drug remdesivir have not been successful. The maker of the drug Gilead Sciences says that the trial for the experimental treatment was poorly characterized in media reports and not conclusive. Meanwhile, shares of Intel Corp. fell in after-hours trade after the chip maker reported better-than-expected results beat butoffered a downbeat outlook.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
title_cleaned: DOW FUTURES PULL SLIGHTLY THURSDAY EVENING HOUSE PASSES BILL REPLENISH CORONAVIRUSAID PACKAGE

title: Dow futures bounce around Tuesday evening after stock market ends at about 2-week low
description:
U.S. stock-index futures on Tuesday swung between slight gains and losses in thinly traded action, after the broader market finished at about the lowest level in about two weeks. Futures for the Dow Jones Industrial Average were last up around 56 points, or 0.2%, the S&P 500 index rose 6.9 points, or 0.2%, and Nasdaq-100 futures gained 23.5 points, or 0.3%,. After the regular session the U.S. Senate on Tuesday approved a nearly $500 billion aid package for small businesses and hospitals hit hard by the coronavirus pandemic, setting up a vote in the House of Representatives as President Donald Trump threw his support behind the measure. Trump, during a Tuesday evening news briefing centered on the country's response to the coronavirus epidemic, said that he would aim to ban immigration for a 60-day period, citing a need to focus on "American workers" after the pandemic hurt business activity. In regular trade Tuesday, the Dow fell 631.56 points, or 2.7%, at 23,018, the S&P 500 index lost 86.60 points, or 3.1%, to close at 2,736.56, with both benchmarks finishing at their lowest levels since April 7, according to FactSet data. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq Composite Index retreated 297.50 points, or 3.5%, to end at 8,263.23, marking the lowest close since April 13.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
title_cleaned: DOW FUTURES BOUNCE TUESDAY EVENING ENDS 2WEEK LOW

title: The Dow's bounce is so far unanimous, with all 30 stocks gaining ground
description:
The Dow Jones Industrial Average's bounce early Wednesday, following the first two-day drop in three weeks, is so far unanimous, as all 30 components are gaining ground in premarket trading. Leading the way, shares of Pfizer Inc. rose 3.6%, Boeing Co. tacked on 2.4%, Intel Corp. advanced 1.9% and Microsoft Corp. climbed 1.8%. The most active stock was Apple Inc.'s , which gained 1.4%. Dow futures rallied 251 points, or 1.1%, after the Dow tumbled 1,224 points, or 5.0%, over the past two days.

Market Pulse Stories are Rapid-fire, short news bursts on stocks and markets as they move. Visit MarketWatch.com for more information on this news.
